description: From Ancient Greek πανήγυρις (panḗguris), from πᾶς- (pâs-, “all”) +‎ ἄγυρις (águris), Aeolic form of ᾰ̓γορᾱ́ (agorā́, “assembly”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₂ger- (“to assemble, gather together”). See panegyric.

entries.meaning: In Ancient Greek religion, a religious festival on a fixed day in honor of a god, often including prayers, games, and panegyrics.

examples: Will there not open a glorious Scene , when God (to use St. Paul's Words) shall celebrate the grand Panegyris?
